question: On July 15, 2008, Phys.org published an article about a catastrophe. Find the explosive force of this catastrophe according to Encyclopedia Britannica, then find the name of the US nuclear test that had the same yield. Your answer should only be the last word of the name of the test.

trajectory.question: On July 15, 2008, Phys.org published an article about a catastrophe. Find the explosive force of this catastrophe according to Encyclopedia Britannica, then find the name of the US nuclear test that had the same yield. Your answer should only be the last word of the name of the test.

trajectory.actor_reasoning: I need to quickly find the specific Phys.org article from July 15, 2008 about a catastrophe to identify the event in question.

tool_executed.name: web_search
tool_executed.result:
Found 3 relevant web results:

1. Tunguska catastrophe: Evidence of acid rain supports ...
   URL: https://phys.org/news/2008-07-tunguska-catastrophe-evidence-acid-meteorite.html
   Site: phys.org
   Date: Jul 15, 2008
   Summary: The Tunguska catastrophe in 1908 evidently led to high levels of acid rain. This is the conclusion reached by Russian, Italian and German researchers.

2. Fatal mine collapse covered 50 acres
   URL: https://phys.org/news/2008-06-fatal-collapse-acres.html
   Site: phys.org
   Date: Jun 2, 2008
   Summary: New calculations show that the deadly Crandall Canyon mine collapse – which registered as a magnitude-3.9 earthquake – began near where ...

3. Scientists Study Earthquake Swarm Near Maupin
   URL: https://phys.org/news/2008-12-scientists-earthquake-swarm-maupin.html
   Site: phys.org
   Date: Dec 23, 2008
   Summary: “These small earthquakes strike Maupin about every other day on average and one looks a lot like another,” he added. The largest events were a ...

trajectory.actor_reasoning: I need Britannica's stated explosive energy for the Tunguska event to identify the yield figure precisely.

args.query: Encyclopaedia Britannica Tunguska explosion megatons Britannica explosive force

tool_executed.name: web_search
tool_executed.result:
Found 3 relevant web results:

1. Tunguska event | Summary, Cause, & Facts - Britannica
   URL: https://www.britannica.com/event/Tunguska-event
   Site: britannica.com
   Date: Oct 24, 2025
   Summary: The energy of the explosion is estimated to have been equivalent to the explosive force of as much as 15 megatons of TNT—a thousand times more ...

2. What Is Known (and Not Known) About the Tunguska Event
   URL: https://www.britannica.com/story/what-is-known-and-not-known-about-the-tunguska-event
   Site: britannica.com
   Summary: The energy of the explosion is estimated to have been equivalent to the explosive power of as much as 15 megatons of TNT—a thousand times more powerful than ...

3. Tunguska event Facts | Britannica
   URL: https://www.britannica.com/facts/Tunguska-event
   Site: britannica.com
   Summary: The energy of the explosion is estimated to have been equivalent to that of about 15 megatons of TNT, a thousand times more powerful than the atomic bomb.

trajectory.actor_reasoning:
The July 15, 2008 Phys.org article is about the Tunguska catastrophe. Encyclopedia Britannica gives its explosive force as about 15 megatons of TNT. The US nuclear test with the same yield is Castle Bravo, so the last word of the test name is:

FINAL ANSWER: Bravo

messages.content:
The July 15, 2008 Phys.org article is about the Tunguska catastrophe. Encyclopedia Britannica gives its explosive force as about 15 megatons of TNT. The US nuclear test with the same yield is Castle Bravo, so the last word of the test name is:

FINAL ANSWER: Bravo
